com.siperian.sif.message.mrm

Class SearchQueryRequest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.siperian.sif.message.SiperianRequest
      • com.siperian.sif.message.SiperianObjectRequest
        • com.siperian.sif.message.mrm.SearchRequestBase
          • com.siperian.sif.message.mrm.SearchQueryRequest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DataProvider, SiperianObjectUidProvider, Serializable

    public class SearchQueryRequest
extends SearchRequestBase
    Retrieves a set of records from an MRM package or a remote package satisfying the specified criteria. SearchQuery API can be used with regular MRM packages, base objects, and AM remote packages.

    Required Parameters:

    • SiperianObjectRequest.setSiperianObjectUid(String) - Specifies the type and the name of the package, base object, cross reference table, cross reference history table, history table, merge history table, or remote package to be queried.

    • SearchRequestBase.setRecordsToReturn(int) - Sets the limit to the number of records that would be returned. See below for information on retrieving large result sets and paging.

    Optional Parameters:

    • Effective Date - the date used to retrieve an effective period of the BO (versioning on). If this parameter is present the result will be the result of BVT calculation for the specified effective period.
    • History Date - The history date for wich the request is executed

    The filter criteria is specified using SearchRequestBase.setFilterCriteria(String) and SearchRequestBase.setFilterParameters(ArrayList) parameters. FilterCriteria contains the filtering conditions specified as a logical expression using any columns of the package that is queried, as well as any of the ANSI SQL functions and operators.

    The FilterCriteria may be used to specify the literal expressions (FIRST_NAME = 'JOHN') or it may be used in combination with the SearchRequestBase.setFilterParameters(ArrayList) to specify the parameterized queries (FIRST_NAME = ?) when the specific values for the parameter are provided as a list through the SearchRequestBase.setFilterParameters(ArrayList) method.

    If FilterCriteria is not specified, all records of SiperianObjectUID will be returned.

    Usage Example:

    The following example searches for a record from the package PARTY_ADDRESS_READ_PKG where PARTY_FULL_NAME starts with 'WAGNER':

    SearchQueryRequest request = new SearchQueryRequest();
    request.setRecordsToReturn(5); //Required
    request.setSiperianObjectUid("PACKAGE.PARTY_ADDRESS_READ_PKG");
    //Required
    request.setFilterCriteria("PARTY_FULL_NAME LIKE ?");
    ArrayList params = new ArrayList(2);
    params.add(new Parameter("WAGNER%"));
    request.setFilterParameters(params);

    SearchQueryResponse response = (SearchQueryResponse) sipClient.process(request);

    The FilterCriteria may also include columns of related base objects. These columns are specified using match path components to the related base objects. The following example searches for a record from the base object C_PARTY with a LAST_NAME of 'WAGNER' with an address located in 'CA' using a match path C_MT_ADDRESS defined on C_PARTY.

    String filterCriteria = "COLUMN.C_PARTY|LAST_NAME = 'WAGNER' AND
    " MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.C_MT_ADDRESS|STATE = 'CA'";

    The FilterCriteria may also include columns of metadata tables like cross reference (XREF), history (HISTORY), matched (MATCHED) and cross reference history (XREF_HISTORY) of the primary base object of the package specified in siperianObjectUid, the base object specified in siperianObjectUid or the related based object referenced using the match paths.

    The following are some example of usage:

    //filter criteria on a column of cross reference of the related address base object
    String filterCriteria = "MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.C_MT_ADDRESS|XREF|State = 'CA'";
    //filter criteria on a column of cross reference history of the related base object
    filterCriteria = "MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.C_MT_ADDRESS|XREF_HISTORY|State = 'CA'";
    //filter criteria on a column of cross reference table of the base object C_PARTY
    //specified in siperianObjectUid
    filterCriteria = "COLUMN.C_PARTY|XREF|LAST_NAME = 'WAGNER'";

    The search results may also include data from related tables using joinUids. At most one joinUid may be specified, which has to be a match path component to a related table. The following example searches for records from the C_PARTY base object with a LAST_NAME of 'WAGNER' and also includes data from the related base object C_PARTY_NAME using the match path C_MT_PARTY_NAME in the joinUid.

    SearchQueryRequest request = new SearchQueryRequest();
    request.setRecordsToReturn(5); //Required
    request.setSiperianObjectUid("BASE_OBJECT.C_PARTY");
    List joinUids = new ArrayList();
    joinUids.add("MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.C_MT_PARTY_NAME");
    request.setJoinUids(joinUids);
    //Required
    request.setFilterCriteria("PARTY_FULL_NAME LIKE ?");
    ArrayList params = new ArrayList(2);
    params.add(new Parameter("WAGNER%"));
    request.setFilterParameters(params);

    SearchQueryResponse response = (SearchQueryResponse) sipClient.process(request);

    Performance Considerations:

    SearchQuery is the SIF API's equivalent of the SQL SELECT statement. The most direct analogy is "select for the view" and is subject to same considerations that one makes in constructing well performing queries:

    • Consider the optimal structure of the indexes that need to be put in place in order to support the different search criteria. The specific design considerations for the indexes may be different between the different database platforms supported by the Siperian Hub. Siperian Hub creates and maintains a set of indexes on the key columns by default. Custom indexes need to be created for the queries that use filtering on the regular data columns.

    • Review the structure of the view to ensure that all JOINS are made on well-indexed columns.

    • Avoid using setReturnTotal() = true. Returning the total number of rows satisfying the search criteria requires running a separate query to get the count. This query may create a very significant IO load on the database for those queries that could potentially return a large number of rows.

    • Use sorting for the queries that are designed to return a predictable number of rows. Sorting a large dataset returned by a query with loose query criteria may be extremely expensive.

    • setDisablePaging() = true for the well constrained queries that are known to return a small number of rows, for example retrieving child records for a given parent object using the foreign key.

    • Use the effective date and the history date only when is needed. The BVT calculation can have a big impact on the API performance.

    Retrieving Large Record Sets:

    See SearchRequestBase for information on controlling the number of records to be returned by the query and setting the data page size for paging support.

    Case Sensitivity:

    Under normal conditions, the SearchQuery API is case sensitive. Any filter criteria specified for the request must be in the same case as in the ORS in order for the records to be found. However, the CASE_INDICATOR column in C_REPOS_TABLE can be used to control the case sensitivity of SearchQuery. Possible values for this indicator are: UPPER, LOWER, and NULL. When specified, the value in this column indicates that all data in the corresponding table is in the specified case. The setting of this causes filter criteria to be automatically converted to the appropriate case. Function-based queries are not required to implement case insensitive searches. In practice, the following behavior can be expected depending on the setting of CASE_INDICATOR:

    • UPPER
      • The where clause and any parameters of the query are converted to upper case prior to executing the request.
      • This assumes that all of the data in the package in the request is stored in upper case.
    • LOWER
      • The where clause and any parameters of the query are converted to lower case prior to executing the request.
      • This assumes that all of the data in the package in the request is stored in lower case.
    • NULL
      • The query specified is executed as is with no case conversions.
      • No assumptions are made about the case of data in the package in the request.

    See Also:
    SearchQueryResponse, GetSearchResultsRequest, GetRequest, SearchMatchRequest, SiperianClient.process(SiperianRequest), Serialized Form

    API Pair: SearchQueryResponse

    API Group: Data Retrieval

      • setDisablePaging

        public void setDisablePaging(boolean disablePaging)
        Disable the paging mechanism, which allows retrieving multiple pages of data by default. Paging has additional costs associated with it. This parameter should be set to true for the queries that have a well predictable number of rows returned.

        Parameters:
        disablePaging - True = disable paging

        See Also:
        GetSearchResultsRequest

      • isRemoveDuplicates

        public boolean isRemoveDuplicates()
        See corresponding setter method for details.

        Returns:
        True = remove duplicates from the result set

      • setRemoveDuplicates

        public void setRemoveDuplicates(boolean removeDuplicates)
        Enable or disable de-duplication of the result set. Defaults to false. Enabling this option can degrade the performance of this request. It should be enabled only when there is a possibility of duplicates in the result set due to the structure of the query. E.g. - a query for a party based on attributes of its child address record could result in the same party being returned several time.

        Parameters:
        removeDuplicates - True = remove duplicates from the result set

      • isAdvancedMode

        public boolean isAdvancedMode()
        See corresponding setter method for details
        Returns:
        true - when there is a need to use advanced mode of query processing

      • setAdvancedMode

        public void setAdvancedMode(boolean advancedMode)

        Enable or disable special mode of search query processing. Defaults to false.
        When this mode is enabled, advanced operators in filterCriteria are supported.
        Currently only EXISTS and COUNT can be used. Please notice, that these operators do not use exact SQL syntax, but instead provide their own.

        Valid examples:

        • COUNT(MT_ADDRESS) < 0
        • COUNT(MT_ADDRESS, MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.MT_ADDRESS|STATE_CD = 'CA') > 0
        • EXISTS(MT_ADDRESS, MATCH_PATH_COMPONENT.MT_ADDRESS|STATE_CD = 'CA')
        Parameters:
        advancedMode - true - when there is a need to use advanced mode of query processing

      • getEffectiveDate

      • setHistoryDate

        public void setHistoryDate(Date historyDate)
        Specifies the date for which the values of the base object will be returned. The values returned are based at this point in history.

        Parameters:
        historyDate - the base object values at this point in history
